Dear Editor,
In the present modern era of healthcare driven by a 
deluge of data, Large Language Models (LLMs) are a 
medical resource to be reckoned with and provide robust 
support for a better global response to health and well -
ness issues. However, it also poses a more urgent chal -
lenge to the unequal development of healthcare resources 
in global regions.
Currently, the relationship between LLMs and global 
regional development is still unclear. Therefore, this 
study aims to explore this issue.
Global overview of the development of LLMs
Among all countries and regions worldwide, 86.7% of 
countries and regions hold attention and application to 
the LLMs (Fig.  1A), with 60.4% further reaping relevant 
subsequent benefits (Fig. 1B).
Resource-rich countries and regions, such as China and 
India, or high-development countries and regions, such 
as USA, exhibit higher and more steady levels of attention 
and application (China = 12110, Ranked 1st; USA = 7372, 
Ranked 2nd; India = 2744, Ranked 3rd ) toward the LLMs 
and furthermore receive more subsequent impacts

(Fig.  2A-B). Other resource-related indicators likewise 
demonstrate similar behavior patterns, such as regional 
gross domestic product, regional internet penetration 
rate and regional net electricity production (Fig.  2C-D 
and I-L).
In addition, in terms of development-related indicators, 
regions with a higher development index exhibit a higher 
level of attention and application ( R = 0.541, P < 0.001) 
toward the LLMs and, consequently, a higher level of 
subsequent impact ( R = 0.514, P < 0.001) from them, a 
behavioral pattern that is more significant at the regional 
education level (Fig. 2E-H).
Comprehensive analysis revealed that surge of LLMs 
exacerbates global regional inequalities in healthcare 
resources, highlighting the urgency and importance of 
targeted policies and international assistance.
Responding to global inequalities in healthcare 
resources exacerbated by the LLMs requires a strategy 
that involves multiple levels and diverse stakeholders [ 1, 
2]. Firstly, infrastructure should be invested in less devel -
oped regions to provide the primary conditions for using 
the LLMs. Secondly, local governments should formulate 
policies to encourage the development and use of the 
LLMs. Finally, the relevant authorities should provide 
education and training on the LLMs to generalize the 
knowledge of these technologies and provide hands-on 
training.
Indeed, in low-resource or underdeveloped regions, 
promoting the relevant applications of the LLMs is of 
unusual significance. In resource-poor regions, LLMs 
can help healthcare professionals gain more comprehen -
sive medical knowledge and improve diagnostic accu -
racy, thus alleviating the problem of insufficient medical 
resources to a certain extent [1, 3]. Nonetheless, there are 
also diverse challenges in this regard [4].
